segment.source: description: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Windows Phone Silverlight app to a Windows 10&\#160;Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: description: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Windows Phone Silverlight app to a Windows 10&\#160;Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: title: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore1
segment.target: title: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore1

segment.source: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore1
segment.target: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore1

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Windows Phone Silverlight app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Windows Phone Silverlight app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: With Windows 10, you can create a single app package that your customers can install onto a wide range of devices, and that's what we'll do in this case study.
segment.target: With Windows 10, you can create a single app package that your customers can install onto a wide range of devices, and that's what we'll do in this case study.

segment.source: See Guide to UWP apps.
segment.target: See Guide to UWP apps.

segment.source: The app we'll port consists of a ListBox bound to a view model.
segment.target: The app we'll port consists of a ListBox bound to a view model.

segment.source: The view model has a list of books that shows title, author, and book cover.
segment.target: The view model has a list of books that shows title, author, and book cover.

segment.source: The book cover images have Build Action set to Content and Copy to Output Directory set to Do not copy.
segment.target: The book cover images have Build Action set to Content and Copy to Output Directory set to Do not copy.

segment.source: The previous topics in this section describe the differences between the platforms, and they give details and guidance on the porting process for various aspects of an app from XAML markup, through binding to a view model, down to accessing data.
segment.target: The previous topics in this section describe the differences between the platforms, and they give details and guidance on the porting process for various aspects of an app from XAML markup, through binding to a view model, down to accessing data.

segment.source: A case study aims to complement that guidance by showing it in action in a real example.
segment.target: A case study aims to complement that guidance by showing it in action in a real example.

segment.source: The case studies assume you've read the guidance, which they do not repeat.
segment.target: The case studies assume you've read the guidance, which they do not repeat.

segment.source: Note When opening Bookstore1Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.
segment.target: Note When opening Bookstore1Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.

segment.source: Downloads
segment.target: Downloads

segment.source: Download the Bookstore1WPSL8 Windows Phone Silverlight app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore1WPSL8 Windows Phone Silverlight app.

segment.source: Download the Bookstore1Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore1Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.

segment.source: The Windows Phone Silverlight app
segment.target: The Windows Phone Silverlight app

segment.source: Here’s what Bookstore1WPSL8—the app that we're going to port—looks like.
segment.target: Here’s what Bookstore1WPSL8—the app that we're going to port—looks like.

segment.source: It's just a vertically-scrolling list box of books beneath the heading of the app's name and page title.
segment.target: It's just a vertically-scrolling list box of books beneath the heading of the app's name and page title.

segment.source: how bookstore1wpsl8 looks
segment.target: how bookstore1wpsl8 looks

segment.source: Porting to a Windows 10 project
segment.target: Porting to a Windows 10 project

segment.source: It's a very quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore1WPSL8, and include the copied files in the new project.
segment.target: It's a very quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore1WPSL8, and include the copied files in the new project.

segment.source: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.
segment.target: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.

segment.source: Name it Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: Name it Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore1WPSL8 to Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore1WPSL8 to Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).

segment.source: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.
segment.target: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.

segment.source: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.
segment.target: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.

segment.source: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.
segment.target: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.

segment.source: Each time you copy a file or folder, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.
segment.target: Each time you copy a file or folder, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.

segment.source: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.
segment.target: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).

segment.source: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.
segment.target: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.

segment.source: We can keep the App.xaml, and App.xaml.cs that Visual Studio generated for us in the Windows 10 project.
segment.target: We can keep the App.xaml, and App.xaml.cs that Visual Studio generated for us in the Windows 10 project.

segment.source: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore1WPSL8 namespace to Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore1WPSL8 namespace to Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.
segment.target: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.

segment.source: In the imperative code in the view model source file, these porting changes are needed:
segment.target: In the imperative code in the view model source file, these porting changes are needed:

segment.source: Change to and then use the Resolve command on it.
segment.target: Change to and then use the Resolve command on it.

segment.source: Delete the property and use IntelliSense to add the correct property name: .
segment.target: Delete the property and use IntelliSense to add the correct property name: .

segment.source: Use the Resolve command on .
segment.target: Use the Resolve command on .

segment.source: Use the Resolve command on .
segment.target: Use the Resolve command on .

segment.source: Delete using and .
segment.target: Delete using and .

segment.source: Change the value returned by the Bookstore1Universal\_10.BookstoreViewModel.AppName property from "BOOKSTORE1WPSL8" to "BOOKSTORE1UNIVERSAL".
segment.target: Change the value returned by the Bookstore1Universal\_10.BookstoreViewModel.AppName property from "BOOKSTORE1WPSL8" to "BOOKSTORE1UNIVERSAL".

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml, these porting changes are needed:
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml, these porting changes are needed:

segment.source: Change to (don't forget the occurrences in property element syntax).
segment.target: Change to (don't forget the occurrences in property element syntax).

segment.source: Delete the and namespace prefix declarations.
segment.target: Delete the and namespace prefix declarations.

segment.source: Change "clr-namespace" to "using" in the remaining namespace prefix declaration.
segment.target: Change "clr-namespace" to "using" in the remaining namespace prefix declaration.

segment.source: We can choose to correct markup compilation errors very cheaply if we want to see results soonest, even if that means temporarily removing markup.
segment.target: We can choose to correct markup compilation errors very cheaply if we want to see results soonest, even if that means temporarily removing markup.

segment.source: But, let's keep a record of the debt we accrue by doing so.
segment.target: But, let's keep a record of the debt we accrue by doing so.

segment.source: Here it is in this case.
segment.target: Here it is in this case.

segment.source: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .
segment.target: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .

segment.source: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .
segment.target: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .

segment.source: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .
segment.target: In the root Page element in MainPage.xaml, delete .

segment.source: In the data template, delete the references to the and TextBlock styles.
segment.target: In the data template, delete the references to the and TextBlock styles.

segment.source: In the StackPanel, delete the references to the and TextBlock styles.
segment.target: In the StackPanel, delete the references to the and TextBlock styles.

segment.source: Let's work on the UI for the mobile device family first, and we can consider other form factors after that.
segment.target: Let's work on the UI for the mobile device family first, and we can consider other form factors after that.

segment.source: You can build and run the app now.
segment.target: You can build and run the app now.

segment.source: Here's how it looks on the mobile emulator.
segment.target: Here's how it looks on the mobile emulator.

segment.source: the uwp app on mobile with initial source code changes
segment.target: the uwp app on mobile with initial source code changes

segment.source: The view and the view model are working together correctly, and the ListBox is functioning.
segment.target: The view and the view model are working together correctly, and the ListBox is functioning.

segment.source: We mostly just need to fix the styling and get the images to show up.
segment.target: We mostly just need to fix the styling and get the images to show up.

segment.source: Paying off the debt items, and some initial styling
segment.target: Paying off the debt items, and some initial styling

segment.source: By default, all orientations are supported.
segment.target: By default, all orientations are supported.

segment.source: The Windows Phone Silverlight app explicitly constrains itself to portrait-only, though, so debt items \#1 and \#2 are paid off by going into the app package manifest in the new project and checking Portrait under Supported orientations.
segment.target: The Windows Phone Silverlight app explicitly constrains itself to portrait-only, though, so debt items \#1 and \#2 are paid off by going into the app package manifest in the new project and checking Portrait under Supported orientations.

segment.source: For this app, item \#3 is not a debt since the status bar (formerly called the system tray) is shown by default.
segment.target: For this app, item \#3 is not a debt since the status bar (formerly called the system tray) is shown by default.

segment.source: For items \#4 and \#5, we need to find four Universal Windows Platform (UWP)TextBlock styles that correspond to the Windows Phone Silverlight styles that we were using.
segment.target: For items \#4 and \#5, we need to find four Universal Windows Platform (UWP)TextBlock styles that correspond to the Windows Phone Silverlight styles that we were using.

segment.source: You can run the Windows Phone Silverlight app in the emulator and compare it side-by-side with the illustration in the Text section.
segment.target: You can run the Windows Phone Silverlight app in the emulator and compare it side-by-side with the illustration in the Text section.

segment.source: From doing that, and from looking at the properties of the Windows Phone Silverlight system styles, we can make this table.
segment.target: From doing that, and from looking at the properties of the Windows Phone Silverlight system styles, we can make this table.

segment.source: Windows Phone Silverlight style key
segment.target: Windows Phone Silverlight style key

segment.source: UWP style key
segment.target: UWP style key

segment.source: PhoneTextExtraLargeStyle
segment.target: PhoneTextExtraLargeStyle

segment.source: TitleTextBlockStyle
segment.target: TitleTextBlockStyle

segment.source: PhoneTextSubtleStyle
segment.target: PhoneTextSubtleStyle

segment.source: SubtitleTextBlockStyle
segment.target: SubtitleTextBlockStyle

segment.source: PhoneTextNormalStyle
segment.target: PhoneTextNormalStyle

segment.source: CaptionTextBlockStyle
segment.target: CaptionTextBlockStyle

segment.source: PhoneTextTitle1Style
segment.target: PhoneTextTitle1Style

segment.source: HeaderTextBlockStyle
segment.target: HeaderTextBlockStyle

segment.source: To set those styles, you can just type them into the markup editor or you can use the Visual Studio XAML Tools and set them without typing a thing.
segment.target: To set those styles, you can just type them into the markup editor or you can use the Visual Studio XAML Tools and set them without typing a thing.

segment.source: To do that, you right-click a TextBlock and click Edit Style > Apply Resource.
segment.target: To do that, you right-click a TextBlock and click Edit Style > Apply Resource.

segment.source: To do that with the TextBlocks in the item template, right click the ListBox and click Edit Additional Templates > Edit Generated Items (ItemTemplate).
segment.target: To do that with the TextBlocks in the item template, right click the ListBox and click Edit Additional Templates > Edit Generated Items (ItemTemplate).

segment.source: There is an 80% opaque white background behind the items, because the default style of the ListBox control sets its background to the system resource.
segment.target: There is an 80% opaque white background behind the items, because the default style of the ListBox control sets its background to the system resource.

segment.source: Set on the ListBox to clear that background.
segment.target: Set on the ListBox to clear that background.

segment.source: To left-align the TextBlocks in the item template, edit it again the same way as described above and set a Margin of on both TextBlocks.
segment.target: To left-align the TextBlocks in the item template, edit it again the same way as described above and set a Margin of on both TextBlocks.

segment.source: After that is done, because of changes related to view pixels, we need to go through and multiply any fixed size dimension that we haven’t yet changed (margins, width, height, etc) by 0.8.
segment.target: After that is done, because of changes related to view pixels, we need to go through and multiply any fixed size dimension that we haven’t yet changed (margins, width, height, etc) by 0.8.

segment.source: So, for example, the images should change from 70x70px to 56x56px.
segment.target: So, for example, the images should change from 70x70px to 56x56px.

segment.source: But, let’s get those images to render before we show the results of our styling.
segment.target: But, let’s get those images to render before we show the results of our styling.

segment.source: Binding an Image to a view model
segment.target: Binding an Image to a view model

segment.source: In Bookstore1WPSL8, we did this:
segment.target: In Bookstore1WPSL8, we did this:

segment.source: In Bookstore1Universal, we use the ms-appx URI scheme.
segment.target: In Bookstore1Universal, we use the ms-appx URI scheme.

segment.source: So that we can keep the rest of our code the same, we can use a different overload of the System.Uri constructor to put the ms-appx URI scheme in a base URI and append the rest of the path onto that.
segment.target: So that we can keep the rest of our code the same, we can use a different overload of the System.Uri constructor to put the ms-appx URI scheme in a base URI and append the rest of the path onto that.

segment.source: Like this:
segment.target: Like this:

segment.source: Universal styling
segment.target: Universal styling

segment.source: Now, we just need to make some final styling tweaks and confirm that the app looks good on desktop (and other) form factors as well as mobile.
segment.target: Now, we just need to make some final styling tweaks and confirm that the app looks good on desktop (and other) form factors as well as mobile.

segment.source: The steps are below.
segment.target: The steps are below.

segment.source: And you can use the links at the top of this topic to download the projects and see the results of all the changes between here and the end of the case study.
segment.target: And you can use the links at the top of this topic to download the projects and see the results of all the changes between here and the end of the case study.

segment.source: To tighten up the spacing between items, find the data template in MainPage.xaml and delete the attribute from the root Grid.
segment.target: To tighten up the spacing between items, find the data template in MainPage.xaml and delete the attribute from the root Grid.

segment.source: If you want to give the page title a little more breathing room, you can reset the bottom margin of to on the page title TextBlock.
segment.target: If you want to give the page title a little more breathing room, you can reset the bottom margin of to on the page title TextBlock.

segment.source: Now, we need to set 's Background to the correct default value so that the app looks appropriate when running on all devices no matter what the theme is.
segment.target: Now, we need to set 's Background to the correct default value so that the app looks appropriate when running on all devices no matter what the theme is.

segment.source: Change it from to .
segment.target: Change it from to .

segment.source: With a more sophisticated app, this would be the point at which we'd use the guidance in Porting for form factor and user experience and really make optimal use of the form factor of each of the many devices the app can now run on.
segment.target: With a more sophisticated app, this would be the point at which we'd use the guidance in Porting for form factor and user experience and really make optimal use of the form factor of each of the many devices the app can now run on.

segment.source: But, for this simple app, we can stop here and see how the app looks after that last sequence of styling operations.
segment.target: But, for this simple app, we can stop here and see how the app looks after that last sequence of styling operations.

segment.source: It actually looks the same on mobile and desktop devices, although it's not making best use of space on wide form factors (but we'll investigate how to do that in a later case study).
segment.target: It actually looks the same on mobile and desktop devices, although it's not making best use of space on wide form factors (but we'll investigate how to do that in a later case study).

segment.source: See Theme changes to see how to control the theme of your app.
segment.target: See Theme changes to see how to control the theme of your app.

segment.source: the ported windows 10 app
segment.target: the ported windows 10 app

segment.source: The ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device
segment.target: The ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device

segment.source: An optional adjustment to the list box for Mobile devices
segment.target: An optional adjustment to the list box for Mobile devices

segment.source: When the app is running on a Mobile device, the background of a list box is light by default in both themes.
segment.target: When the app is running on a Mobile device, the background of a list box is light by default in both themes.

segment.source: That may be the style that you prefer and, if so, then there's nothing more to do.
segment.target: That may be the style that you prefer and, if so, then there's nothing more to do.

segment.source: But, controls are designed so that you can customize their look while leaving their behavior unaffected.
segment.target: But, controls are designed so that you can customize their look while leaving their behavior unaffected.

segment.source: So, if you want the list box to be dark in the dark theme—the way the original app looked—then follow these instructions.
segment.target: So, if you want the list box to be dark in the dark theme—the way the original app looked—then follow these instructions.

segment.source: Conclusion
segment.target: Conclusion

segment.source: This case study showed the process of porting a very simple app—arguably an unrealistically simple one.
segment.target: This case study showed the process of porting a very simple app—arguably an unrealistically simple one.

segment.source: For instance, list controls can be used for selection or for establishing a context for navigation; the app navigates to a page with more details about the item that was tapped.
segment.target: For instance, list controls can be used for selection or for establishing a context for navigation; the app navigates to a page with more details about the item that was tapped.

segment.source: This particular app does nothing with the user's selection, and it has no navigation.
segment.target: This particular app does nothing with the user's selection, and it has no navigation.

segment.source: Even so, the case study served to break the ice, to introduce the porting process, and to demonstrate important techniques that you can use in real UWP apps.
segment.target: Even so, the case study served to break the ice, to introduce the porting process, and to demonstrate important techniques that you can use in real UWP apps.

segment.source: The next case study is Bookstore2, in which we look at accessing and displaying grouped data.
segment.target: The next case study is Bookstore2, in which we look at accessing and displaying grouped data.
